html:
1.17.23  9:36 am   Do you think that I should learn sheet music? I already know a lot of music theory, and music sheets kinda confuse me

      different industries use it in different amounts. unless you are getting into a classical orchestra you probably won't need to know every little detail about everything, but in general it would probably be cool for you to learn how bars and barlines work, how rhythms work, and also learn about chord symbols. just so you can talk about things with your friends and co-workers a little more clearly

1.16.23  7:09 pm   i really want to get more into jazz . could you send any recommendations my way

      the word jazz makes my head explode because it means like 12,000 different things over the past 100 years. it all comes down to what made you ask this. what you're really looking for is probably whatever it was at that exact moment that made you think you want this. For example, let's say the reason you are asking this is because last night you walked past a music venue that said "jazz" on it, and it made you feel good for whatever reason and that's what made you think that what you're looking for is probably called 'jazz'. Or maybe you met a cool person who told you they like 'jazz'. Either way, your best option is to recall the scenario that inspired this desire, and go back there and you'll probably find a trail of bread crumbs from there to your next destination

1.16.23  5:55 pm   you've talked about writing your own code to automate parts of animation / music production. would you ever consider publishing some of that code? or is it too specific to your own process/setup.

      it's extremely specific to my system. it will show up in the reality page probably within the next 5 to 10 years

1.16.23  5:53 pm   thought on politics?

      sports, but with opinions instead of a ball

1.16.23  5:41 pm   thoughts on 6/4 time? someone told me no one makes songs in 6/4

      a lot of people do it without knowing it. they'll put 3/4 on the page and have tiny bars when it really might have been better to say 6/4. there's no reason 'we wish you a merry christmas', 'happy birthday', 'you make me feel like a natural woman', and trillions of other popular songs from every generation wouldn't really be better off saying 6/4 on the page. or, depending on the tempo, be converted to 6/8 or even written as 4/4 and put everything in triplets. a lot of different notation options for songs in 3-feels. But songs with a 4-feel tend to just use 4/4 because it's all groups of 4 within groups of 4 within groups of 4, so 4/4 will always fit. I'd say about 20% of songs use some kind of 3-feel, and within that you're going to have a million different ways of writing the same thing. so those time signatures (6/4, 6/8, etc) would appear less common, but they are used for the same type of music which again i'd say comprises at least 10% of music from all generations

1.16.23  10:50 am   Bill you are an awesome person and music creator, but about how long did it take to learn all the instruments that you play?

      it's not clear where the finish line would be. the starting line for learning most of the instruments would be in my childhood, and the finish line could range anywhere from slightly later in childhood or very very far in the future such as never, depending on how you want to look at it

1.16.23  7:28 am   hi bill,
i think i need some advice. i have a synthesizer that i would like to use to make my own music. the problem is that i don't have a daw besides audacity, which i have heard has limitations. almost everyone i look up to uses some variation of logic, but i feel like completely switching to a new os would be even more of a problem. speaking of that, i really don't even have a usable computer because mine is very bad and freezes up trying to load a browser let alone handle a daw or a video editor. anyway i guess i am here to see if you have any advice? i have all these ideas but no way to document them really, and it's getting to be a lot

      this could be a blessing. maybe you can find 1 sound in the keyboard and then learn to just play it while singing at the same time. and then record that on 1 microphone, like the one on your phone. there's a lot you probably want to learn about yourself and how you make music, and usually it's best to just start with the simplest thing that's available. you don't even know what you want yet, and the advantage with using exactly what you have is it's probably a unique set of tools that aren't exactly what any other person has. you're gonna have a unique sound automatically. it reminds me of that guy that lived next to a spatula, so he made spatula music. there's not very much spatula music out there, so, someone's gotta do it

1.15.23  10:37 pm   i appreciate how your music has the dynamics intact, the drums pop out in a nice way and the instruments seem to blend together naturally,

how and when did you decide how to handle dynamics, and how do you avoid going too far with processing the sounds? (compressors, limiters, amps)

      i just try to do a little better each time. or, if i did it too good last time, do it a little worse

1.15.23  7:52 pm   what's the best way to go about developing really good relative pitch? i've been trying to transcribe the chords to various songs, and i think i'm getting better at it, but is there anything else i should be doing? there are a ton of tests online to see if you can identify certain intervals, but do those actually help? any thoughts would be appreciated

      the more time you spend at an instrument, preferably of the piano/keyboard family, the better you will be. it's just like learning french from being in france. just happens, the more time you spend there
